title: Tom Holland claims Disney's feud with Sony over Spider-Man was the 'most stressful time' of his life
text:
Tom Holland admitted that the period in which Disney and Sony's feud over Spider-Man went public was the most 'stressful' in his life.

The actor, 23, made the claim during an appearance at ACE Comic Con Midwest in Chicago, Illinois, on Sunday, as he spoke about his character's uncertain future when it seemed like Peter Parker was out of the Marvel Cinematic Universe.

When asked about when he had been most stressed, Tom explained: 'Well… maybe the whole Disney/Sony thing when that happened, that was a bit of a stressful week.

Candid: Tom Holland claimed on Sunday that Disney's feud with Sony over Spider-Man was the 'most stressful time' of his life... after the actor convinced them to make a deal

'I’m sure there’s some contractual obliged where I can’t say anything about anything, so I’m just going to keep my mouth shut.'

For a time, it looked like the superhero was unlikely to return to the MCU after Sony claimed in September that the 'door is closed' on them making a deal with Disney.

It's thanks to Tom that the two companies were able to come to an agreement, as The Hollywood Reporter claimed he used his role as Nathan Drake in Sony's new Uncharted film as leverage to persuade the pair to strike a bargain.

According to the publication's sources, the actor made several appeals to Disney chairman and CEO Bob Iger and Sony film chairman Tom Rothman to make a deal.

Honest: When asked about his most difficult time at ACE Comic Con Midwest, he said: 'Maybe the whole Disney/Sony thing when that happened, that was a bit of a stressful week'

And in September it was announced that Marvel would make a third Spider-Man solo film, and the character would also appear in another Marvel film.

It was also revealed that Disney will earn 25 per cent of net gross on the hero's solo film in return for paying into 25 per cent of its budget.

In celebration Tom posted an Instagram clip of Leonardo DiCaprio in The Wolf Of Wall Street saying: 'You know what? I'm not leaving. I'm not leaving. I'm not f***ing leaving!'

It emerged in August that Disney and Sony were at loggerheads over financing and that if the issue was not resolved, the MCU would lose Spider-Man.

Tom remained publicly optimistic, telling Entertainment Weekly: 'Who knows what the future holds? But all I know is that I’m going to continue playing Spider-Man and having the time of my life. It’s going to be so fun, however we choose to do it.'

He added: 'The future for Spider-Man will be different, but it will be equally as awesome and amazing, and we’ll find new ways to make it even cooler.'

The rapprochement the studios arrived at this Thursday stipulates that Disney will rake in a fourth of the profits, Variety sources claim.

In the original deal, Disney got 5% of first-dollar gross. The feud over the summer allegedly sprang from Sony's desire to stick to this arrangement, while Disney wanted to evenly split the financing.

Doing his part: It's thanks to Tom that the two companies were able to come to an agreement, as The Hollywood Reporter claimed he used his role in Sony's new Uncharted film as leverage

Delighted: When a deal was finally made, Tom posted an Instagram clip of Leonardo DiCaprio in The Wolf Of Wall Street saying 'You know what? I'm not leaving' in celebration

Amy Pascal, who was at Sony until 2015 and was a producer on both Homecoming and Far From Home via her own company, is back for the third film as well.

Sony acquired the rights to Spider-Man in the late 1990s and quickly churned out a hit trilogy of live-action movies between 2002 and 2007.

Directed by Sam Raimi, these films starred Leonardo's pal Tobey Maguire as the title superhero and Kirsten Dunst as his love interest Mary Jane Watson.

Sony then rebooted the franchise with the 2012 feature The Amazing Spider-Man, starring erstwhile Hollywood hot couple Andrew Garfield and Emma Stone.

Iconic: Sony acquired the rights to Spider-Man in the late 1990s and quickly churned out a hit trilogy of live-action movies between 2002 and 2007

Trying again: Sony then rebooted the franchise with the 2012 feature The Amazing Spider-Man, starring erstwhile Hollywood hot couple Andrew Garfield and Emma Stone

The 2014 sequel The Amazing Spider-Man 2 was a box office disappointment and divided critics, earning a 52% on Rotten Tomatoes.

Plans for future Spider-Man films at Sony were shelved and the company reached their original deal with Disney, ushering the character into the MCU.

Spider-Man adjacent movies have since begun to crop up at Sony again, including a movie about the villain Venom last year starring Tom Hardy and the forthcoming film Mobius starring Jared Leto.

The next MCU Spider-Man film is set to be released on July 16, 2021.
